{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18522,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Alepis flavida, commonly known as a type of mistletoe, thrives in environments that mimic its native conditions. It generally requires moderate watering. Ensure the host tree is adequately hydrated but avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. It's crucial to consider the climate conditions, as mistletoes tend to be drought-tolerant once established. Water the host plant when the top 2 inches of soil are dry, and ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging. Mimicking its natural environments, such as ensuring sporadic watering during dry periods, will help keep Alepis flavida healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alepis flavida requires moderate sunlight, similar to its native environment as a mistletoe residing on host trees. Ideally, it should be exposed to dappled sunlight or partial shade. Direct, harsh afternoon sunlight might be too intense, potentially causing leaf burn. The plant generally benefits from morning sunlight and filtered light in the afternoons, mimicking the canopy conditions of its natural habitat. Ensuring the host tree captures enough light can indirectly benefit Alepis flavida, aiding in its growth and sustenance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Alepis flavida is minimal but essential to prevent overgrowth and manage the health of the host tree. Pruning should be performed during the plant's dormant period, ideally late winter or early spring. Trim back any dead or diseased tissue to promote healthy growth. Since mistletoes are semiparasitic, it's vital to limit their spread by cutting back to the base of the plant where it attaches to the host. This helps prevent Alepis flavida from overwhelming the host plant. Regularly inspect for any signs of disease or excessive attachment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Alepis flavida"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18225,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brugmansia sanguinea requires consistent watering to thrive, but it is crucial to avoid overwatering. The plant prefers well-drained soil, so ensure that the pot or garden area has good drainage. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry. In warmer months, you might need to water more frequently due to increased evaporation. During cooler months, reduce the watering frequency to prevent root rot. Always adjust your watering schedule based on the weather and the specific growing conditions your Brugmansia is experiencing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brugmansia sanguinea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, the plant should receive between six to eight hours of filtered light per day. Direct sunlight during the hottest part of the day can scorch the leaves, so some shade is beneficial in hotter climates. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window but away from direct afternoon light. Outdoors, a location with morning sun and afternoon shade would be suitable. In cooler climates, Brugmansia can tolerate more direct light without leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brugmansia sanguinea is important to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring while the plant is dormant. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Additionally, trim back any branches that disrupt the desired shape of the plant. Light pruning throughout the growing season can also help to maintain its appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and reduce the risk of spreading disease. Remember to wear gloves, as the plant’s sap can be toxic."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red Angel's Trumpet","description":"Brugmansia sanguinea, the red Angel's Trumpet, is a South American species of flowering plants that grow as shrubs or small trees.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Red Angel's Trumpet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Brugmansia sanguinea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ideally, place the growth area in indirect sunlight or a completely shaded location. Maintaining a stable temperature and humidity level is crucial, so avoid areas with high fluctuations in light and temperature."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a conventional requirement for Trametes villosa as it is with flowering plants. However, in a cultivation setting, periodically removing any dead or excessively mature fruiting bodies may be necessary to maintain the health of the culture and aesthetic appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19710,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euploca polyphylla prefers moderately moist soil. It is important to water the plant thoroughly when the soil feels dry to the touch, but take care to avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. During the active growth period in spring and summer, increase the frequency of watering, but reduce it during the dormant period in fall and winter. Ensuring good drainage is key to prevent waterlogging, so it's advisable to let the top inch of soil dry out between watering sessions to maintain the health of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euploca polyphylla thrives in full sun to partial shade, though it prefers a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Adequate sunlight is crucial for its growth and flowering, as insufficient light may result in leggy foliage and reduced blooms. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching. When grown indoors, place the plant near a bright, sunny window but away from harsh mid-day sun to ensure the plant receives adequate light for optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Euploca polyphylla is not routinely necessary, but can be beneficial in maintaining a tidy appearance and encouraging bushy growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves and stems to prevent the spread of diseases. If the plant becomes leggy, pinching back the growing tips during the growing season can encourage a more compact form. Prune sparingly, particularly in the off-season, to avoid stress and to maintain the natural shape and blooming potential of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"pineland heliotrope","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["pineland heliotrope"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Euploca polyphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18326,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dillenia suffruticosa, commonly known as the \"shrubby dillenia,\" prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It's crucial to maintain a good level of moisture without waterlogging, as excess water can cause root rot. During dry periods, especially in its natural tropical habitat, it may require watering a couple of times a week to sustain its vibrant foliage and flowers. In contrast, during the rainy season, supplemental watering may not be necessary as natural rainfall can suffice. Always allow the top inch of soil to slightly dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dillenia suffruticosa thrives in full sun conditions, requiring around 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. This plant is naturally found in open clearings and sunny locations, so ensuring it has ample sunlight is crucial for its development. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. If growing indoors or in partially shaded areas, consider supplementing with grow lights to ensure it receives enough light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dillenia suffruticosa involves removing dead or diseased branches to maintain plant health and encourage growth. It's also beneficial to prune any overcrowded branches to allow for better air circulation and sunlight penetration within the plant. This is typically done after the flowering season to shape the plant and control its size. Regularly checking for and trimming any suckers that may arise at the plant’s base is important to direct nutrients to the main branches."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Simpoh Air","description":"Dillenia suffruticosa (simpoh ayer) is a species of Dillenia found in tropical South East Asia in secondary forest and swampy ground. It's important to monitor the plant's appearance and adjust its location or shading if you notice any signs of distress, such as wilting or faded leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arctopus echinatus is generally minimal. However, during its initial growth phase or in particularly dry conditions, regular watering is essential to ensure healthy development. Ensure that the soil remains moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering. Use mulch around the base to retain moisture and regulate soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Geobalanus oblongifolius thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. In regions where the sun is particularly intense, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. If planted in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer fruits. Its adaptability to different light conditions makes it well-suited for various landscape settings. Position the plant where it can receive plenty of bright, indirect sunlight while being protected from the harshest midday sun in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geobalanus oblongifolius is generally minimal, focusing on maintaining its shape and promoting dense, healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve circulation and aesthetics. Light pruning can be done to manage size and encourage bushier growth, however, avoid heavy pruning as it could stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18820,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leucopogon fasciculatus, commonly known as a type of heather, generally prefers well-drained soil and does not require constant watering. It is best to water this plant moderately, ensuring that the soil remains slightly moist but never waterlogged. During the growing season in spring and summer, increase the watering frequency to support its growth, but always let the top layer of soil dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so be cautious during the cooler months when the plant's water needs decrease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucopogon fasciculatus thrives in partial to full sun conditions. For optimal growth, it should be placed in a location where it can receive several hours of sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some shade, lack of adequate sunlight can result in reduced flowering and a less vigorous plant overall. In particularly hot or dry regions, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from intense sunlight, which might otherwise cause stress or foliage burn. Adjust sunlight exposure based on the plant's specific environmental requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leucopogon fasciculatus is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. The best time to prune is after the plant has flowered, typically in spring or early summer. Use clean, sharp shears to trim back spent blooms and any leggy or unruly branches. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this can damage the plant and hinder its ability to regenerate. Regular light pruning helps keep the plant healthy and aesthetically pleasing, promoting dense foliage. \t"}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tall Mingimingi","description":"Leucopogon fasciculatus (also known as tall mingimingi) is a species of shrub within the heath family. An example occurrence of L. fasciculatus is in the red and silver beech forests admixed with rimu and miro podocarps on northern South Island, New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Tall Mingimingi"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Leucopogon fasciculatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19317,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agathosma ovata, commonly known as the round-leaf buchu, prefers regular watering to thrive, especially in well-drained soil. It is adapted to dry conditions, so it requires moderate watering, about once a week, allowing the topsoil to dry out between waterings. Ensure the plant is not overwatered, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. During the warmer months, you might need to increase watering slightly to accommodate the increased evaporation, but always ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging. In winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters a less active growth stage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agathosma ovata thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a south-facing window can mimic its natural sun exposure. Ensure that it is not in deep shade, as insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and reduced flowering. Adjust the location according to seasonal sun patterns to ensure consistent light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agathosma ovata should be done minimally to maintain its natural shape and encourage bushiness. Light pruning can be carried out after flowering to remove spent blooms and any dead or diseased branches. This not only helps maintain its aesthetic appeal but also promotes healthy growth. Be cautious not to prune too aggressively, as this can affect the plant's flowering potential for the next season. Regular pinching of the tips can help in maintaining a compact form, especially if the plant starts becoming leggy or uneven in growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"False Buchu","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["False Buchu"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Agathosma ovata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19418,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pennisetum clandestinum, commonly known as Kikuyu grass, requires regular watering to maintain its lush green appearance, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. It should be watered deeply and infrequently, about once a week, to encourage deep root growth. However, in extreme heat or drought conditions, it may require more frequent watering. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases. Allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between watering to ensure that the roots are not sitting in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pennisetum clandestinum thrives best in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to grow vigorously. It can tolerate partial shade but will perform poorly in dense shade areas, leading to sparse growth and less robust grass. If grown in shaded areas, it might become leggy and more prone to diseases such as fungal infections. If possible, plant Kikuyu grass in open spaces with unobstructed access to sunlight to ensure optimal health and coverage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning or mowing Kikuyu grass is essential to keep it healthy and prevent it from becoming invasive. It should be mowed regularly to maintain a height of about 1 to 2 inches, depending on the usage and location. This will encourage lateral growth and a thick, lush lawn while also minimizing seed head production. During the active growing season, you might need to mow once a week, while less frequent mowing is required in the cooler months. Always ensure your mower blades are sharp to avoid tearing the grass."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"kikuyu grass","description":"The tropical grass species Pennisetum clandestinum is known by several common names, most often kikuyu grass, as it is native to the region of East Africa that is home to the Gĩkũyũ tribe. Because of its rapid growth and aggressive nature, it is categorised as a noxious weed in some regions. However, it is also a popular garden lawn species in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and the southern region of California in the United States,...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["East Africa"],"other_name":["kikuyu grass"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal diseases","Rust","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Pennisetum clandestinum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18722,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lastreopsis hispida, commonly known as a furry or rough tree fern, prefers moderate and consistent moisture in its soil. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. However, do not let the soil completely dry out, as this can damage the plant. Humidity is also beneficial for Lastreopsis hispida, so misting the leaves regularly or placing a humidity tray nearby can help maintain the moisture levels that this fern enjoys."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lastreopsis hispida thrives in indirect sunlight or partial shade conditions, as direct sunlight can scorch its fronds. In its natural habitat, this fern is typically found under a canopy of trees, receiving diffused light. For optimal growth indoors, place it in a spot that receives bright, indirect light, like near an east or north-facing window. If the leaves start browning, it might be a sign that the plant is either getting too much direct light or not enough humidity, so adjustments may be necessary to correct this."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lastreopsis hispida involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and improve the plant's appearance. It's best to use clean, sharp pruning shears and cut fronds off at their base, taking care not to damage the crown. Regular pruning will also help improve air circulation around the plant, preventing fungal infections. Be cautious and avoid excessive pruning as it could stress the plant, especially during its growth period. Ideally, pruning should be performed in spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hairy fern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["hairy fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Lastreopsis hispida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18226,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carissa bispinosa, commonly known as the Natal Plum, prefers moderate watering. It is important to allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant once the top 2-3 inches of soil have dried. In the winter months, reduce watering frequency as the plant requires less moisture. Overwatering can cause yellowing of the leaves and poor plant health, so proper drainage is crucial. Incorporate organic mulch to retain moisture and enhance soil health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carissa bispinosa thrives in full sun to partial shade, ideally requiring about four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. When grown in full sun, the plant exhibits its most vibrant foliage and optimal flowering. However, it can tolerate partial shade, which might result in fewer flowers and slower growth. In regions with extremely hot weather, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives sufficient light for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carissa bispinosa should be done regularly to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and plant health. Lightly trim back long branches to maintain the desired size and shape of the plant, and ensure it does not become too leggy. Pruning helps prevent tangling with the plant's thorny branches, making it safer and more visually appealing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"num-num","description":"Carissa bispinosa grows as a shrub or small tree up to 5 metres (16 ft) tall. Its fragrant flowers feature a white corolla. Fruit is red when ripe. Habitat is woodland and forest from 1,080 metres (3,540 ft) to 1,630 metres (5,350 ft) altitude. Vernacular names for the plant include \"forest num-num\" and \"Y-thorned carissa\". C. bispinosa is native to Malawi, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Swaziland and South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["num-num"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Carissa bispinosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water newly-planted daylilies regularly, ensuring they receive at least an inch of water per week through rainfall or irrigation, especially during the growing season. It's best to water early in the morning to allow the foliage to dry by evening, which helps reduce the risk of disease. Avoid overhead watering to prevent wetting the foliage. Once established, reduce watering frequency, but increase during extended dry periods to keep the plants vigorous and blooming."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Daylilies thrive in full sun but they can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. Ideally, they should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal blooming. Morning sun combined with afternoon shade is beneficial, especially in areas with intense summer heat, to prevent the flowers from wilting. In cooler climates, providing full sun can encourage better growth and more prolific flowering. While they can grow in partial shade, reduced light may result in fewer flowers and less vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning daylilies involves deadheading spent blooms and trimming back foliage when necessary. After blooming, remove spent flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Cut the flower stalks down to the base after all flowers have bloomed. In late fall or early spring, cut back any dead or damaged leaves to about 2-3 inches from the ground to promote healthy, new growth. Pruning helps prevent diseases by improving air circulation and removing potential habitats for pests. Routine maintenance supports vigorous growth and prolongs the plant's lifecycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Various colors including yellow, orange, red, pink, and purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Various regions as they are hybrids"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites","Thrips"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Hemerocallis × hybrids"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19318,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tetragonia fruticosa, commonly known as New Zealand spinach, prefers regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. It's crucial to ensure good drainage to avoid root rot, so water thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry. In hotter climates, this plant may require more frequent watering, especially during dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to fungal diseases. Mulching around the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tetragonia fruticosa thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimum growth and leaf production. While it can tolerate some shade, too much may result in leggy growth and reduced foliage yield. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure that the plant receives adequate bright light, possibly through supplementing with grow lights. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tetragonia fruticosa involves removing any dead or diseased leaves and stems to help maintain a healthy plant. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. Pinch back the growing tips to promote bushier growth and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. During regular maintenance, lightly trim the plant to control its shape and size, which also encourages more growth and leaf production. Be cautious not to over-prune, as the plant needs sufficient foliage to photosynthesize and stay healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sprawling Seacoral","description":"Tetragonia fruticosa L. aka kinkelbossie  is an endemic Southern African coastal perennial shrub or scrambler well-suited to dune sand stabilisation and often browsed by livestock and game. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18921,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hibiscus taiwanensis requires a consistent watering schedule to thrive. It is best to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. During the growing season in spring and summer, you should water it more frequently, ensuring the top inch of soil remains moist. However, allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In the fall and winter months, reduce watering as growth slows. Always use lukewarm water and avoid getting the foliage wet to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hibiscus taiwanensis thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering and growth, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. However, in extremely hot climates, it may require some afternoon shade to protect it from scorching. Placing the plant near a south or west-facing window if grown indoors can provide adequate sunlight. If the plant does not receive enough light, it may result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. Ensure the location is well-lit but sheltered from strong winds."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hibiscus taiwanensis should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It is recommended to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Additionally, cut back any overcrowded or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. This will not only keep the plant healthy but also promote more abundant flowering. Avoid excessive pruning, as this could stress the plant. After pruning, apply a balanced fertilizer to support new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Taiwan cotton rose","description":"Hibiscus taiwanensis is a native plant in Taiwan, which distributes in China and low altitude in Taiwan. It is a species of plant in the Malvaceae family. The form of flower is different from Hibiscus mutabilis in China which is double. Utilizing well-draining soil will help prevent moisture from sitting around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ursinia nana thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but prolonged shade may lead to fewer flowers and leggy growth. In extremely hot and arid regions, providing afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. Ensuring the plant has enough sunlight is crucial for maintaining its compact form and dynamic flowering display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ursinia nana involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Regular deadheading will help the plant focus its energy on producing new flowers rather than seed setting. Cut back any overgrown or leggy stems to promote a bushier growth habit. In late autumn, prune back the plant slightly if needed to help it maintain its shape. Avoid heavy pruning, as this could reduce flowering in the upcoming season. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18723,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leonotis ocymifolia, commonly known as lion's ear, prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. During the growing season, water regularly to keep the soil slightly moist but not soggy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage. It's better to underwater than overwater; the plant is somewhat drought-tolerant. Observe the plant for signs of wilting, which indicates it needs more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leonotis ocymifolia thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish. This exposure encourages strong growth and abundant blooming. It can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in fewer flowers and a less vigorous plant. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window or provide supplementary lighting to ensure it receives adequate light. If transitioning from indoor to outdoor settings, acclimate the plant gradually to prevent leaf scorch caused by sudden direct sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leonotis ocymifolia helps promote a bushier appearance and encourages more blooms. Trim back any dead or damaged stems at any time of the year to maintain plant health. In early spring, prune the plant back more rigorously to control its size and shape; cutting back about a third of the old growth works well. During the blooming season, deadheading, or the removal of spent flowers, can encourage continuous blooming throughout its growing period. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rock Lionspaw","description":"Leonotis ocymifolia, occasionally referred to as the minaret flower is a flowering plant of the Lamiaceae (mint) family. The plant is used in Ethiopian folk medicine and found in Eastern Africa spanning from Sudan to South Africa. The plant is reasonably drought-resistant and wind tolerant. Unlike the similar Leonotus leonuris, in the ocymifolia, the tubular flowers are bolder and larger.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Rock Lionspaw"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cuttings"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Leonotis ocymifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18002,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gambelia speciosa, commonly known as the island snapdragon, requires moderate watering. During its growing season, which is primarily during the spring and fall, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. In hotter, drier months, allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. The plant is drought-tolerant once established, so reduce watering frequency during summer to mimic its native dry conditions. Ensure proper drainage is provided to avoid water accumulation, which can harm the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering and growth, provide at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help protect against scorching and wilting, but ensure it still receives ample light during the morning. The plant's native habitat is often sunny coastal areas, so it is well-adapted to bright conditions. Insufficient sunlight may result in leggy growth and fewer blooms, thus maintaining adequate light exposure is crucial for its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gambelia speciosa is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. It is best done in late winter or early spring, before the growing season begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems, and cut back overgrown or leggy branches to encourage new, bushy growth. Pruning after flowering can also help manage size and redirect energy to plant vigor rather than seed production. Be cautious while pruning as excessive cutting may reduce flowering; always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Island Bush Snapdragon","description":"Gambelia speciosa, previously classified as Galvezia speciosa, is commonly known as showy island snapdragon or showy greenbright.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Baja California","Mexico"],"other_name":["Island Bush Snapdragon"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gambelia speciosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18811,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hymenophyllum multifidum requires consistently moist conditions to thrive. You should water this plant regularly to keep the soil damp but not waterlogged. It is essential to avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings as this plant naturally grows in humid environments like shaded forests and near waterfalls. Using distilled or rain water is preferable, as tap water with its chemicals and salts can harm the plant over time. Maintaining high humidity around the plant, such as by misting or using a humidity tray, can also help in keeping the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hymenophyllum multifidum requires indirect, filtered sunlight to flourish, mimicking the dappled light it naturally receives in its native habitat. It thrives best in low to moderate light conditions, often benefiting from environments that offer some shade. Direct sunlight should be avoided, as it can scorch the fronds, causing them to brown and dry out. An east or north-facing window is ideal, or a bright room where the plant is protected from harsh direct rays. If natural light is insufficient, fluorescent lights can be a good supplement to help keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hymenophyllum multifidum is a gentle process, primarily focused on maintaining the plant's health and aesthetic. However, avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot; ensure that the soil has good drainage. In pots, water thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry, allowing excess water to drain away. During the growing season, more frequent watering may be needed, while in cooler months, reduce watering to prevent soggy conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spermacoce remota thrives in full sun to partial shade environments, preferring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching and stress. If grown indoors or in shaded areas, ensure that the plant receives bright, indirect sunlight to mimic its natural habitat conditions; supplementing with grow lights may be necessary if natural light is insufficient. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so finding a balance is key for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spermacoce remota involves removing dead or diseased stems and leaves to promote healthy growth and prevent pest infestations. Regularly trim back overgrown or leggy stems to encourage bushier growth and maintain a tidy appearance. This is best done in the spring or early summer. If the plant is not flowering as much as desired, a light prune can stimulate new growth and increase flowering. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts just above a leaf node. Be mindful not to remove more than one-third of the plant at a time."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Woodland false buttonweed","description":"Spermacoce remota, the woodland false buttonweed, is a species of plant in the Rubiaceae. It is native to the southeastern United States (Texas, Florida, Georgia, Alabama), West Indies (Bermuda, Bahamas, Hispaniola, Puerto Rico, the Cayman Islands, Trinidad, Lesser Antilles, etc.), Mexico, Central America and South America. It is naturalized in Taiwan, Southeast Asia (Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia), China (Guangdong), India, Sri Lanka, New Guinea, Mauritius and many other oceanic islands (including Hawaii and the Galápagos).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Woodland false buttonweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Spermacoce remota"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18092,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Portulacaria afra, commonly known as the Elephant Bush, prefers relatively infrequent watering, making it ideal for drought-prone environments. Water thoroughly until the soil is moist, then allow it to dry out completely before the next watering. During the summer growing season, this may mean watering every 7 to 10 days, while in the winter months, water only once a month, if at all. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage and be cautious about the frequency and volume of water used."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Portulacaria afra thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate several hours of direct sunlight each day. It does well in full sun to partial shade. When outdoors, place the plant in a location where it can receive morning sun and some afternoon shade to prevent sunburn, especially in very hot climates. Indoors, the plant should be placed near a sunny windowsill, ideally south or west facing, where it can get at least 4 to 6 hours of light daily for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Portulacaria afra helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. It can be trimmed back during the growing season in spring or early summer. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut stems and branches just above a leaf node or where another branch is growing. You can remove leggy growth or shape the plant to fit aesthetic preferences. Don’t remove more than one-third of the plant at once to avoid stress. Cuttings can be propagated to grow new plants if desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Elephant bush","description":"Portulacaria afra (known as elephant bush, dwarf jade plant, porkbush and spekboom in Afrikaans) is a small-leaved succulent plant found in South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Elephant bush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Portulacaria afra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Inadequate light can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering, so finding the right balance of light exposure is crucial for maintaining its vibrant appearance and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Callianthe picta involves removing dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health and encourage bushier growth. Prune minimally during the moss's dormant periods to avoid unnecessary stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Apple-moss","description":"Bartramia pomiformis, the common apple-moss, is a species of moss in the Bartramiaceae family. After the flowering period, it's a good idea to trim the plant back to control its size and encourage healthier growth in the next season. Regular deadheading of spent flowers can help to prevent unwanted self-seeding and prolong the blooming period. In late autumn or early spring, cut back dead stems to about 10-15 cm above the ground. This practice also reduces the likelihood of pests and diseases, ensuring a tidy plant structure as new growth emerges."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"fireweed","description":"Chamaenerion angustifolium is a perennial herbaceous flowering plant in the willowherb family Onagraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17003,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Silphium integrifolium, also known as rosinweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers moderate watering. It's best to water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage. In the first year, more regular watering may be necessary to establish a strong root system. During periods of extreme heat or drought, slight increases in watering may be required, but once established, the plant generally thrives with minimal supplemental water, relying on natural rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silphium integrifolium thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Ideally, place the plant in a south-facing location where it can receive ample sunlight throughout the day. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching, but care should be taken to maintain primarily sunny conditions for optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Silphium integrifolium is generally straightforward, focusing on encouraging healthy growth and maintaining its shape. After the plant blooms in late summer, prune back spent flower stalks to promote a neat appearance and prevent unwanted self-seeding. In late fall or early spring, cut back the entire plant to about 6 inches above the ground to remove any damaged or dead growth. This will help stimulate new growth in the spring. Be careful not to over-prune during the growing season, as this can inhibit blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"prairie rosinweed","description":"Silphium integrifolium is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18318,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Freesia laxa prefers to be kept in moderately moist soil, but it does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. During its growing season, water the plant regularly to ensure the soil remains evenly moist, but allow the top inch to dry out between waterings. In the dormant period, which occurs in winter, reduce watering significantly to prevent bulb rot. If grown in a container, ensure proper drainage to avoid standing water. Be mindful of the plant's pot size, as overly large pots can retain moisture too long, which can harm the bulb and roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Freesia laxa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct morning sun, but the intense afternoon sun may scorch its leaves, especially in hot climates. Ideally, place it near a south or east-facing window where it receives plenty of light but is shielded from the harshest rays. In regions with milder summers, it may be placed outdoors in light shade. If you notice the plant stretching or becoming leggy, it may be a sign that it's not receiving enough light, and you should consider moving it to a brighter location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Freesia laxa generally involves removing spent blooms and yellowing foliage to encourage new growth and enhance flowering. As the plant blooms in the spring and summer, deadhead the flowers by cutting the stem close to the base to prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production. After the growing season, allow the foliage to die back naturally, as this helps the plant gather energy for the next bloom cycle. Remove any dead or diseased leaves to maintain plant health and to deter pests and diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scarlet Kammetjie","description":"Freesia laxa or False Freesia (syn. Anomatheca cruenta, Anomatheca laxa, Lapeirousia cruenta, Lapeirousia laxa) is a small cormous flowering plant from the eastern + southern Africa from Kenya to northeastern South Africa. It is grown in gardens as an ornamental plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Scarlet Kammetjie"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Bulb","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Freesia laxa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

To maintain optimal moisture, it should be watered frequently enough to ensure that the substrate remains damp but not waterlogged. The plant should be watered with distilled or rainwater if possible, as it can be sensitive to the minerals in tap water. It is important to avoid letting the substrate dry out completely, as this can cause serious damage to the plant. During periods of dry weather or indoor growth, increasing humidity around the plant can also help it thrive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Conocephalum conicum prefers low to moderate indirect sunlight, as excessive direct sun can scorch its tissues. If natural light is limited, artificial grow lights may be used, but should not be too intense. Regularly assess the plant to ensure it is not receiving too much light, as this can lead to browning or bleaching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Conocephalum conicum is generally not necessary, as this liverwort naturally forms compact, low-growing mats. However, any dead or decaying tissue can be gently removed to maintain the plant’s aesthetic and health. If the colony becomes too dense or starts to spread beyond its desirable boundaries, sections can be trimmed back to keep it in check. Use sterilized scissors or a sharp knife to make clean cuts, and be gentle when handling the plant to avoid excessive damage to its delicate structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Great Scented Liverwort","description":"Conocephalum conicum, the great scented liverwort, common mushroom-headed liverwort or snakeskin liverwort, is a liverwort species in the genus Conocephalum .","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Great Scented Liverwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Conocephalum conicum"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19115,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex uncinata, commonly known as the \"hooked sedge,\" requires regular watering to maintain evenly moist soil, but it should not be waterlogged. It's resilient and can tolerate short periods of drought, but for optimal growth, ensure a consistent moisture level, especially during the growth phase in spring and summer. In cooler months, reduce watering but never allow the soil to dry out completely. Using mulch around the base can help retain soil moisture. Be sure to assess the plant's environment to adjust the watering schedule appropriately depending on indoor or outdoor growth conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex uncinata thrives in partial to full shade conditions but can tolerate some sun, especially in cooler climates. Ideally, the plant should receive filtered sunlight, such as dappled sunlight through trees. Too much direct sunlight, particularly in hotter environments, may cause the foliage to brown. However, in cooler, temperate regions, it can handle more sun exposure. When planted indoors, place it near a window where it can receive indirect light. Adjust the plant's position based on observation—if the leaves appear scorched, move it to a shadier area."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex uncinata involves removing dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth and maintain a tidy appearance. This should typically be done at the end of the winter or in early spring before new growth begins. Trim the plant down to ground level, leaving about 2-3 inches of growth. Regularly remove any yellowing or brown leaves throughout the year to prevent disease. While pruning, be careful not to cut into any new green growth as this can stunt the plant's development. Pruning also helps in managing its spread if grown in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bastard Grass","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Bastard Grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex uncinata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18913,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Breynia vitis-idaea, also known as the Snow Bush, prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate standing water. It thrives best with regular watering that mimics its natural subtropical habitat. During winter, reduce the frequency of watering to prevent root rot. Ensure the pot has good drainage to allow excess water to escape, preventing root rot. Use tepid water ideally to avoid shocking the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Breynia vitis-idaea prefers bright, indirect light to maintain its vibrant leaf coloration. Too much direct sunlight may scorch its leaves, while too little light can cause the color to fade and the plant to grow leggy. This plant can adapt to a variety of light conditions but will thrive best with consistent, bright indirect sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Breynia vitis-idaea should be done in the growing season, primarily in spring and summer, to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Trim back any leggy stems and dead or diseased branches to promote a healthy appearance. You can also pinch back new growth to encourage branching and an overall dense appearance. Ensure that your pruning tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate which this fungus relies on for moisture absorption, thus indirectly affecting its growth. Ensuring a habitat that simulates forest floor conditions with dappled or filtered light can promote healthy development and fruiting. Maintaining shade conditions with possible sporadic dappled sunlight though tree canopy or shading materials is beneficial."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Ileodictyon cibarium as it is a fungus, not a plant. Be mindful not to disrupt the mycelium network in the substrate, as this is vital for their lifecycle and regeneration."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Basket Fungus","description":"Ileodictyon cibarium is a saprobic species of fungus in the family Phallaceae. Too much shade can inhibit growth, while excessive direct sunlight can damage the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Costus woodsonii is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It’s best done in the spring or after the flowering season ends. Remove any dead or diseased canes at ground level, along with any yellow or brown leaves. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18515,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Plagianthus regius, commonly known as the ribbonwood or lowland ribbonwood, prefers well-drained soil, which means it should not sit in waterlogged conditions. Water the plant moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In its early growth stages, increase watering frequency to support healthy development. Mature trees are somewhat drought-tolerant, so reduce watering in cooler months or if the plant is established. Always consider local rainfall and ensure the soil is draining properly, particularly if the plant is in a pot or a garden with poor drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plagianthus regius thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, position the plant where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, planting in full sunlight helps ensure the densest foliage and most prolific blooming. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade may protect it from excessive stress. Consider its native New Zealand origins when planning its placement, as it adapts well to a range of sunlight conditions, from coastal to more shaded native habitats."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Plagianthus regius primarily to maintain its shape and to remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before new growth starts. Lightly thinning the interior branches can improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, promoting a healthier plant. Additionally, remove any crossing branches to prevent damage from rubbing. Be careful not to over-prune, as Plagianthus regius benefits from its naturally graceful form. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, minimizing stress to the plant and reducing disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lowland ribbonwood","description":"Plagianthus regius or lowland ribbonwood is a tree that is endemic to New Zealand. The common name is simply ribbonwood. The Māori name is manatu but is also known as houi, manaui manatu, puruhi and whauwhi.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Lowland ribbonwood"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Plagianthus regius"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18124,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leucocoprinus cepistipes, commonly known as a type of 'dung-loving Lepiota,' is a species of fungus rather than a typical plant, and it doesn't require watering in the traditional sense. Instead, its growth is primarily determined by environmental moisture levels, which need to be high for the fungus to fruit. If cultivating indoors or outdoors, maintain consistent humidity by using loose, well-draining substrates kept moist but not overly wet, simulating its natural damp habitat. Adequate moisture helps mycelium spread and produce fruiting bodies."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Unlike plants that require sunlight for photosynthesis, Leucocoprinus cepistipes does not need direct sunlight. However, it does benefit from indirect or diffused natural light or low artificial lighting for optimal growth and identification of readiness for spore dispersal. Direct sunlight and high temperatures can dry out the substrate, hindering its growth. Maintaining the appropriate level of ambient light and humidity mimics its natural habitat and encourages the healthy development of the fungal fruiting bodies. Keep it shaded or under filtered light if it's outdoors."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a fungal species, Leucocoprinus cepistipes does not undergo pruning in the way that vascular plants do. Instead, when cultivating or managing this fungus, you should focus on harvesting mature fruiting bodies when they are fully developed. This involves carefully plucking or cutting the mushrooms at the base to prevent damage to the mycelium, which can continue to produce new fruiting bodies under suitable conditions. Regular removal of these mushrooms can also help manage spore distribution in controlled environments."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"onion-stalk parasol","description":"Leucocoprinus cepistipes (often spelled cepaestipes), is a species of fungus in the family Agaricaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19310,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gladiolus hirsutus prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in late winter to spring. Water the plant moderately to ensure that the soil is never dry, yet not waterlogged. Soil that retains some moisture but has excellent drainage is ideal. During its dormancy in summer, the watering should be significantly reduced. If planted in containers, ensure adequate drainage holes. It's important to adjust watering relative to rainfall and humidity conditions, avoiding excessive water to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gladiolus hirsutus thrives in full sun to partial shade, although it performs best with full sun exposure. At least six hours of direct sunlight per day will support optimal growth and flowering. If you live in a hotter region, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the foliage from burning. In areas with less sunlight, these plants may experience reduced flowering. It's essential, however, to ensure the plant has enough light to perform photosynthesis efficiently, which will keep it healthy and promote robust blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Gladiolus hirsutus involves removing the spent flower spikes after blooming, cutting them back to the ground to encourage the plant to focus energy on its bulb development, rather than seed production. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17004,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Simsia calva, commonly known as Awnless bush sunflower, prefers a well-draining soil to prevent water from accumulating around its roots, which can cause rot. It's a drought-tolerant plant, so you should allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Aim to water it once every 1-2 weeks, depending on the climate and soil type. During the growing season, water deeply but infrequently to encourage strong root growth. In areas with regular rainfall, additional watering might not be necessary. In winter, reduce watering significantly to protect against root rot, as the plant is less active and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Simsia calva thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal blooming and growth. It is well-suited for open spaces with minimal shade, as sunlight is crucial for its energy production and flower production. If grown in partial shade, the plant may become leggy with fewer flowers. The awnless bush sunflower is heat-tolerant and can handle high temperatures, making it ideal for sunny gardens. Ensure it's placed where it can receive ample sunlight throughout the day, especially in cooler climates where sunlight is less intense."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Simsia calva benefits from regular pruning to maintain its shape and encourage more blooms. Prune back any dead or wilted flowers to promote new growth and extend the blooming period. To keep the plant bushy and prevent it from becoming leggy, trim the branches by about one-third in early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches throughout the year. If the plant becomes overgrown, you can cut it back more drastically, by up to half its size, after the flowering season to rejuvenate it and promote a healthy structure for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Awnless Bushsunflower","description":"Simsia calva, commonly known as the awnless bushsunflower, is a perennial or subshrub that is found in the Southwest United States (Texas and New Mexico), as well as Mexico, the West Indies, and both Central and South America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Awnless Bushsunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Simsia calva"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It can adapt to partial shade, but its growth and flowering may be less prolific. When planted in an environment with ample sunlight, the plant tends to produce more vibrant and abundant flowers. However, if grown in a region with intense heat or harsh summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent sunburn on the leaves and ensure that the plant remains healthy and resilient. Ensure it receives adequate ventilation and airflow in all lighting conditions to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bulbine frutescens is generally straightforward and not overly demanding. Remove any spent flowers to promote continued blooming and improve the plant's appearance. You can also cut back the stems if they become too long or leggy to encourage a bushier growth habit. If the leaves show signs of damage or disease, trim them back to maintain the plant's health. Pruning is ideally done in the late winter or early spring before the new growth starts, ensuring that the plant remains vigorous and attractive."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wild Kopieva","description":"Bulbine frutescens is a species of flowering plant in the genus Bulbine, native to southern Africa (South Africa, Lesotho, Swaziland).","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Wild Kopieva"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Bulbine frutescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Therefore, keeping them in a shaded spot where they get diffused light would mimic their natural habitat, helping them grow healthily and efficiently."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Lactarius pubescens or other fungi. Unlike plants that benefit from pruning to encourage healthy growth and shape, mushrooms do not require any form of trimming. Instead, focus on creating and maintaining optimal conditions for growth such as maintaining humidity, appropriate temperature, and nutrient-rich soil. If harvesting, simply cut the mushroom at the base of its stalk. It's essential during harvesting to ensure the surrounding mycelium remains undisturbed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Downy milk cap","description":"Lactarius pubescens, commonly known as the downy milk cap, is a species of fungus in the family Russulaceae. Insufficient light can lead to poor growth and a lack of vibrant colors. Overall, bright light is key for healthy growth and vibrant coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sarracenia rosea is relatively simple, primarily focusing on removing dead or dying leaves. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18417,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gillenia stipulata, commonly known as Bowman's root, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water the plant deeply once a week to ensure the roots receive adequate moisture. Avoid soggy conditions as this can lead to root rot. During hot, dry spells, increase watering frequency to maintain a moist environment. Mulching around the plant can help retain moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Less frequent watering is required in cooler months when the plant is dormant. Always check the soil moisture level before watering to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gillenia stipulata thrives best in partial shade to dappled sunlight but can tolerate full sun in cooler climates. In hotter regions, providing afternoon shade is crucial to prevent leaf scorch. Ideally, the plant should receive 3 to 6 hours of sunlight each day, with morning sun and afternoon shade being optimal. If planted in full sun, additional water may be necessary to keep the plant healthy. It’s essential to observe the plant's response to its light conditions and adjust its placement if signs of stress, like wilting or leaf browning, appear."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gillenia stipulata should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Remove any dead or damaged stems to keep the plant healthy and vigorous. Cutting back the plant by about one third helps encourage a bushier growth habit. After flowering, deadhead spent blooms to maintain a tidy appearance and potentially promote a second flush of flowers. Be careful not to prune too late in the season as it can affect flowering. Regular pruning will help improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"American ipecac","description":"Gillenia stipulata (American ipecac) is a plant in the genus Gillenia, in the Rosaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American ipecac"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Gillenia stipulata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19705,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythranthe dentata, commonly known as monkeyflower, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. It requires regular watering, especially during dry spells, to maintain the soil moisture evenly. Ensure that the plant does not dry out completely between waterings. You can do this by providing a light watering each time the top inch or so of soil begins to feel dry to the touch. Be careful to avoid getting water on the leaves if possible, as excessive moisture can lead to fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythranthe dentata thrives in conditions with partial to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive around 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, preferably in the morning or late afternoon, to avoid the intense midday sun that can cause leaf scorch. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or east-facing window for adequate light. In overly shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. However, in very hot or dry climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erythranthe dentata is not typically extensive but can help maintain a healthy and attractive plant. Trim back any dead or fading flowers to encourage further blooming, which is known as deadheading. You can also cut back any dead or damaged foliage to maintain appearance and health. In late fall or early spring, trim the plant to remove old growth and to shape it as needed. Always use sharp, sterile tools to make clean cuts and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coastal Monkeyflower","description":"Erythranthe dentata is a species of monkeyflower known by the common names coastal monkeyflower and toothleaf monkeyflower. It is native to the western coast of North America from British Columbia to northern California, where it grows in moist habitat. It was formerly known as Mimulus dentatus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Coastal Monkeyflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Erythranthe dentata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18320,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chrysothemis pulchella, commonly known as Sunset Bells, prefers evenly moist soil. Water the plant regularly but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which is spring to late summer, it's important to maintain consistent moisture levels. In the dormant winter months, you should reduce watering slightly as the plant's water needs decrease when growth slows. Always ensure that the plant is in a container with good drainage to avoid waterlogged soil, which can be detrimental to its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chrysothemis pulchella thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Although it can tolerate a bit of direct sunlight, especially in the early morning or late afternoon, excessive harsh midday sun can scorch its leaves. For optimal growth, place the plant near a window that receives filtered or diffused light throughout the day. If growing the plant outdoors, choose a spot under a tree or structural shading that offers dappled sunlight. During the winter months, when the sunlight is not as intense, the plant may appreciate as much indirect light as possible to sustain its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chrysothemis pulchella involves removing spent blooms and any yellowing leaves. This should be done regularly to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's appearance. Prune back any leggy or unruly stems to promote bushier growth. It's best to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage to the plant. The ideal time for a more thorough pruning is at the beginning of the growing season in spring. This will set the plant up for healthy new growth and a more attractive form throughout the growing period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sunset Bells","description":"Chrysothemis pulchella (also known as sunset bells, black flamingo, copper leaf' or simply chryothemis) is a tender tropical perennial plant that belongs to the Gesneriaceae family. It can be used as a shade area house plant or interior ornamental plant or in a greenhouse.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Tropical America"],"other_name":["Sunset Bells"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Chrysothemis pulchella"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19214,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drimia elata prefers well-draining soil and should be watered sparingly, as it is drought-tolerant. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which is typically in spring and early summer, water the plant more frequently, but always ensure the soil is not waterlogged. In its dormant period, during fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing natural rainfall to suffice if it's outdoors. Use tepid water if possible, and ensure the pot has adequate drainage holes to allow excess water to escape."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drimia elata thrives in bright, indirect light but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the early morning or late afternoon. If placed indoors, a south or west-facing window with filtered sunlight will suffice. Too much direct sunlight during the hottest part of the day can scorch its leaves, so if possible, provide shade or diffuse the light with a curtain. If placed outdoors, ensure it is in a partially shaded area to protect it from the intense midday sun. Adjust the light exposure according to the plant's response and season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Drimia elata is generally minimal and mostly involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain a neat appearance. It is also advisable to cut back any flower stalks once they have finished blooming. This can help the plant conserve energy and potentially stimulate new growth. Use sharp, sterilized pruning scissors to avoid disease transmission. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. Most of the grooming and shaping can be done during the beginning or end of the growing season, allowing the plant to recover and flourish."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Satin Squill","description":"Drimia elata is a species of flowering plant in the family Asparagaceae, subfamily Scilloideae. It is widely distributed in eastern and southern Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa","Namibia"],"other_name":["Satin Squill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Drimia elata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
