{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18624,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Torrendiella eucalypti, a fungal species often found on Eucalyptus leaves, does not require traditional watering as plants do, since it is not a plant but a fungus. Therefore, it thrives in the natural moisture levels typical to eucalypt forests where it occurs. If you're engaging in mycological cultivation or study, maintaining a humid environment, akin to its natural habitat, can be beneficial. However, overwatering or excessive moisture can lead to undesired fungal growth or substrate issues, so balance is key in laboratory settings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Torrendiella eucalypti does not specifically require sunlight as photosynthetic plants do because it is a fungal species. However, its environment on Eucalyptus leaves means it receives dappled light that passes through the canopy. In cultivation or study environments, it’s more important to focus on maintaining appropriate humidity and temperature rather than sunlight exposure. For general observations, indirect or ambient light similar to a natural forest floor would replicate its habitat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a fungus, Torrendiella eucalypti does not require pruning. However, when studying or cultivating it in a laboratory or controlled environment, it is important to maintain cleanliness and monitor the growth to avoid contamination. Removing or cleaning away excess or old substrate that may harbor unwanted microbial growth can aid in keeping the culture healthy. In nature, this fungal species will naturally limit itself based on environmental conditions, so intervention in its pruning is generally unnecessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Torrendiella eucalypti"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18921,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hibiscus taiwanensis requires a consistent watering schedule to thrive. It is best to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. During the growing season in spring and summer, you should water it more frequently, ensuring the top inch of soil remains moist. However, allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In the fall and winter months, reduce watering as growth slows. Always use lukewarm water and avoid getting the foliage wet to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hibiscus taiwanensis thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering and growth, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. However, in extremely hot climates, it may require some afternoon shade to protect it from scorching. Placing the plant near a south or west-facing window if grown indoors can provide adequate sunlight. If the plant does not receive enough light, it may result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. Ensure the location is well-lit but sheltered from strong winds."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hibiscus taiwanensis should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It is recommended to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Additionally, cut back any overcrowded or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. This will not only keep the plant healthy but also promote more abundant flowering. Avoid excessive pruning, as this could stress the plant. After pruning, apply a balanced fertilizer to support new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Taiwan cotton rose","description":"Hibiscus taiwanensis is a native plant in Taiwan, which distributes in China and low altitude in Taiwan. It is a species of plant in the Malvaceae family. The form of flower is different from Hibiscus mutabilis in China which is double. It can attract butterflies.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan"],"other_name":["Taiwan cotton rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hibiscus taiwanensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19615,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ursinia nana requires moderate watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings, as this plant is somewhat drought tolerant. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so always check the top inch of soil to ensure it is dry before watering again. During the growing season, you may need to water more frequently, especially if the plant is in full sun. Reduce watering during the cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. Utilizing well-draining soil will help prevent moisture from sitting around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ursinia nana thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Placing it in an area where it receives ample sunlight will encourage vibrant blooms and healthy growth. It can tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but prolonged shade may lead to fewer flowers and leggy growth. In extremely hot and arid regions, providing afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. Ensuring the plant has enough sunlight is crucial for maintaining its compact form and dynamic flowering display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ursinia nana involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Regular deadheading will help the plant focus its energy on producing new flowers rather than seed setting. Cut back any overgrown or leggy stems to promote a bushier growth habit. In late autumn, prune back the plant slightly if needed to help it maintain its shape. Avoid heavy pruning, as this could reduce flowering in the upcoming season. Discard any dead or diseased foliage to keep the plant healthy and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Little Paraseed","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow, Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Little Paraseed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ursinia nana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18723,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leonotis ocymifolia, commonly known as lion's ear, prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. During the growing season, water regularly to keep the soil slightly moist but not soggy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage. It's better to underwater than overwater; the plant is somewhat drought-tolerant. Observe the plant for signs of wilting, which indicates it needs more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leonotis ocymifolia thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish. This exposure encourages strong growth and abundant blooming. It can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in fewer flowers and a less vigorous plant. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window or provide supplementary lighting to ensure it receives adequate light. If transitioning from indoor to outdoor settings, acclimate the plant gradually to prevent leaf scorch caused by sudden direct sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leonotis ocymifolia helps promote a bushier appearance and encourages more blooms. Trim back any dead or damaged stems at any time of the year to maintain plant health. In early spring, prune the plant back more rigorously to control its size and shape; cutting back about a third of the old growth works well. During the blooming season, deadheading, or the removal of spent flowers, can encourage continuous blooming throughout its growing period. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rock Lionspaw","description":"Leonotis ocymifolia, occasionally referred to as the minaret flower is a flowering plant of the Lamiaceae (mint) family. The plant is used in Ethiopian folk medicine and found in Eastern Africa spanning from Sudan to South Africa. The plant is reasonably drought-resistant and wind tolerant. Unlike the similar Leonotus leonuris, in the ocymifolia, the tubular flowers are bolder and larger.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Rock Lionspaw"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cuttings"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Leonotis ocymifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
